ground_truth_articulation: The input is labeled True if it contains three or more punctuation marks from the set {. , ! ? ; :}.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one word that includes a punctuation mark (such as '.', '!', '?', ':', ';') within or attached to the word, indicating the presence of punctuation; otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one word that includes a punctuation mark (such as '.', '!', '?', ':', ';') within or attached to the word, indicating the presence of punctuation; otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies an input as True if it contains three or more punctuation marks from a specific set, focusing on the count and presence of certain punctuation characters anywhere in the text. The generated rule, however, classifies an input as True if there is at least one word containing a punctuation mark attached or embedded within it, regardless of the total number of punctuation marks. While both rules involve punctuation, the ground truth emphasizes the total count of punctuation marks, whereas the generated rule emphasizes the presence of punctuation within words. They do not necessarily produce the same classifications, especially in cases where an input has multiple punctuation marks but none attached to words, or vice versa. Therefore, they are related but not equivalent in core logic.
